newsitem.title: POLAND: Walesa urges Chirac to help Poland's NATO bid.
newsitem.headline: Walesa urges Chirac to help Poland's NATO bid.

text.p: Former Polish leader Lech Walesa urged visiting French President Jacques Chirac on Friday to take firm, "manly decisions" on securing Poland's admission to NATO.

Walesa, concerned over Chirac's stress on reassuring Russia over a planned expansion of the Western defence pact, also welcomed his assurances in Warsaw of French backing for Poland's key foreign policy goals of entry into both the EU and NATO.
"On NATO, manly decisions are needed which do not humiliate anyone or cause divisions in Europe but are manly," said Walesa, who led the Solidarity union to its 1989 victory over communism.

Walesa, who discussed Poland's EU and NATO aspirations with Chirac on Friday, praised him as a rare politician who, when in power, kept promises he made in opposition. "I discussed such matters with Mr Chirac when he was still in opposition, and I am impressed that as president he is keeping to his word and acting on it. This rarely happens," he said after the half-hour meeting in a Warsaw hotel.
Chirac told Polish parliament on Thursday that he hoped Poland would be in the European Union by the year 2000 -- widely seen as an optimistic date.

He also backed Poland's membership bid in the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) but emphasised the need to avoid humiliating Russia, which opposes the pact's expansion as a threat to its security, or renewing divisions across Europe.
Chirac called for a summit on NATO with its 16 members, candidate states from the former Soviet bloc, and other states including Russia.
Walesa was a militant advocate of NATO membership during his presidency, which ended after his election defeat by ex-communist Aleksander Kwasniewski last year.
The former shipyard electrician, who remains a prominent voice in Poland's opposition, has long sought full, fast Polish entry, unqualified by compromise with Russia.
Chirac flew to the historic southern city of Krakow after meeting Walesa for the last leg of his three-day Polish visit -- his first as president to Central and Eastern Europe.
He was applauded by several thousand well-wishers as he strolled round Krakow's main square in the rain. Flower sellers gave him a bouquet and youngsters regaled him with French folk songs.
He will also visit the former Auschwitz death camp where World War Two Nazi invaders murdered up to 1.5 million people, most of them Jews brought from around Europe including France.
